The Murderbot Diaries by Martha Wells

Add House of Leaves (#269)

I can't say I've ever been "excited" to read a book, but after hearing about _House of Leaves_ I was undeniably excited. I was in the middle of another book when my wife surprised me with this one, and I finished the book I was already reading much more quickly than I normally would have just so I could start reading _House of Leaves_.

If you're looking for a book which lays out all the answers for you and packages things up neatly with a bow, this is not for you ðŸ˜„

---

This book is widely considered "horror" as well but I wasn't sure if a new "Horror" subsection should be created, so I put the entry in the general "Science Fiction" section. If you'd like a "Horror" subsection created as part of this PR, let me know and I can add it and move _House of Leaves_ there!

I've added Neal Asher's *Polity* series to the Science Fiction section, as well as adding Vernor Vinge's _A Deepness in the Sky_ to the hard sci-fi section.  I feel like my description of the *Polity* series is a bit long, but the series includes almost 20 books, including three distinct sub-series and several standalone novels.

Add `Arrival` (#221)

A beautiful film, weaving together memory, languages, and the other. The film is less about aliens and more about our perception of them; like District 9, this film functions as a good mirror for how different people and governments deal with alien interaction. The music is also exceptional.

Merge pull request #196 from RichardLitt/feature/speaker-for-the-dead

Added `Speaker for the Dead`

Removed Soft Science Fiction and Merged Fantasy categories

Soft Science Fiction is ambiguous; most of the novels here could fit in it. When you take into account that it is just the opposite of Hard Science Fiction, which really ought to be a category in my opinion, it was a useless category that was just sucking stuff away from the default category without real reason. I think it is better removed.

Low and High fantasy, as well, is not a useful distinction when there is only one author, and only three examples in both categories. I just merged them into one.

Adding 'The Illustrated Man' by Ray Bradbury

Heard about this book on an episode of Criminal Minds, and it turned out to be one of the weirdest and most disturbing books I've ever read.
Some of the stories are brilliant. When I saw the trailer of Gravity, I immidieatly thought of the story "Kaleidoscope".
